title: OpenClaw Complete Guide

# OpenClaw Complete Guide

## Overview
OpenClaw is a framework for building **persistent AI agents** (referred to as *Claws*) that run continuously, schedule their own work, maintain context across sessions, and orchestrate multiple toolâ€‘enabled agents. While the platform is flexible, the choice of hardware has a direct impact on reliability, uptime, and scalability.

---

## Hardware Compatibility

OpenClaw can be run on any modern serverâ€‘class machine that meets the following baseline requirements:

- **CPU**: 4â€‘core x86_64 (or Apple Silicon Mâ€‘series with Rosetta 2 support)â€¯â‰¥â€¯2â€¯GHz.
- **Memory**: Minimum 8â€¯GB RAM; 16â€¯GB+ recommended for multiple concurrent Claws.
- **Storage**: SSD with at least 50â€¯GB free space for logs, container images, and persistent state.
- **Network**: Stable broadband connection with inbound ports open for webhooks (typically 443/80) and outbound internet access for API calls.
- **OS**: Linux (Ubuntuâ€¯22.04â€¯LTS, Debianâ€¯12, etc.) or macOSâ€¯12+ for development environments.

These specifications are derived from the general guidance in the OpenClaw community and are corroborated by the accessory and workstation guides for the Mac Miniâ€¯[OpenClaw Mac Mini Developer Workstation Specs](https://openclawn.com/openclaw-mac-mini-developer-workstation-specs/) and the hardwareâ€‘software integration articleâ€¯[Seamless Synergy: OpenClaw Mac Mini Hardwareâ€‘Software Integration](https://openclawn.com/openclaw-mac-mini-hardware-software-integration/).

---

## Mac Mini Limitations

While a Mac Mini is an attractive, lowâ€‘cost form factor, several practical constraints make it a **subâ€‘optimal choice for productionâ€‘grade OpenClaw deployments**:

1. **Uptime Risks** â€“ Homeâ€‘grade power and macOS automatic updates can cause unexpected reboots, breaking the â€œalwaysâ€‘onâ€ guarantee of a Claw.
2. **Networking Complexity** â€“ Residential routers often require manual portâ€‘forwarding, dynamic DNS, and TLS certificate management to expose webhook endpoints.
3. **Security Surface** â€“ Running privileged agents on a personal workstation exposes the entire LAN to potential compromise if a Claw is misâ€‘configured.
4. **Scalability Limits** â€“ A single Mac Mini has limited CPU/Memory headroom; scaling to multiple Claws or heavier workloads quickly exhausts resources.
5. **Process Supervision** â€“ macOS lacks builtâ€‘in process supervisors comparable to Linux systemd or Elixir OTP, requiring custom scripts to autoâ€‘restart crashed agents.

These points echo the observations from Andrej Karpathyâ€™s Mac Mini experiment, which highlighted powerâ€‘outage susceptibility, networking hurdles, and the need for external supervisionâ€¯[OpenClaw Mac Mini as a Developer Workstation: Specs for â€¦](https://openclawn.com/openclaw-mac-mini-developer-workstation-specs/).

**Recommendation** â€“ For production or longâ€‘running Claw deployments, prefer a cloudâ€‘hosted or dedicated server environment (e.g., Fly.io, VPS) that provides robust supervision, automatic restarts, and reliable networking.

---

## Claw Variant Recommendations

OpenClaw offers several variants, each tuned for different tradeâ€‘offs:

| Variant | Approx. Code Size | Typical Useâ€‘Case | Key Tradeâ€‘offs |
|---------|-------------------|------------------|---------------|
| **OpenClaw** | Full feature set | Generalâ€‘purpose, multiâ€‘agent orchestration | Higher resource consumption |
| **NanoClaw** | ~4â€¯000â€¯LOC | Lightweight, singleâ€‘agent workloads; easy to audit | Limited builtâ€‘in tools |
| **zeroclaw** | Minimal core | Experimental, sandboxed environments | Minimal persistence |
| **ironclaw** | Moderate | Securityâ€‘focused deployments with stricter sandboxing |
| **picoclaw** | Very small | Edge devices or constrained hardware |

Choosing the right variant depends on the hardware you plan to run on. For a Mac Mini, **NanoClaw** or **picoclaw** are the most feasible, but even these benefit from the robust supervision offered by cloud platforms.

---

## Further Reading & Resources
- **Accessories & Upgrades for Your OpenClaw Mac Mini (2026)** â€“ Practical hardware addâ€‘ons such as locks, trackers, and external SSDsâ€¯[OpenClaw Mac Mini Accessories & Upgrades](https://openclawn.com/openclaw-mac-mini-accessories-upgrades/)
- **The Ultimate Guide to OpenClaw Mac Mini Docks & Hubs (2026)** â€“ Recommendations for connectivity and peripheral expansionâ€¯[OpenClaw Mac Mini Docks & Hubs Guide](https://openclawn.com/openclaw-mac-mini-docks-hubs-guide/)

---
